Optimisation-based proximity queries and penetration depth computation

Optimisation-based proximity queries and penetration depth computation

  • Charbel Fares1,2 &
  • Yskandar Hamam2,3 

Virtual Reality volume 13, pages131–136(2009)Cite this article

  • 86 Accesses

  • 1 Citations

  • Metrics details

Abstract

The virtual reality (VR) was found to be a perfect technique that could be used as a training approach, since it shows many advantages despite its weakness. In the VR some major bottlenecks arises namely the proximity queries (PQ) and penetration depth computation. This paper shows a novel algorithm used to solve those problems. Problems of PQ are ubiquitous within many tasks in computer graphics, virtual environments, robotics, manufacturing, and mechanical design. Interactions in any virtual scene usually involve contact or close proximity between its objects. Determining which pairs of objects are in contact or at close proximity is a complex task in most of the virtual environments. The PQ is the shortest vector over which one object needs to be translated in order to bring the pair in contact.

Introduction

The need to perform fast proximity queries (PQ), including collision detection, tolerance checking, distance calculation, and Penetration depth (PD) computation arises in numerous areas. Some applications include virtual environments, physical-based modeling, computer animation, robotics, haptic, and electronic prototyping. While several of these queries such as collision detection and distance computation have been extensively studied in the field, there is relatively little work on penetration computation that provides a measure of intersection or penetration between two overlapping models.

Given two inter-penetrating rigid polyhedral models, the penetration measure between them can be defined using different formulations. One of the widely used measures for quantifying the amount of intersection is PD, commonly defined as the minimum translational distance required to separate two intersecting rigid models (Dobkin et al. 1993; Cameron and Culley 1986; Cameron 1997). PD is often used in contact resolution for dynamic simulation (Teschner et al. 2004; McKenna and Zeltzer 1990; Mirtich 2000; Stewart and Trinkle 1996), force computation in haptic rendering (McNeely et al. 1999; Gregory et al. 2000), tolerance verification for virtual prototyping (Requicha 1993), and motion planning of autonomous agents (Hsu et al. 1998), etc. Various heuristics such as reducing the frequency of PD computation or estimating PD based on the last closest feature pairs are sometimes used. Fast and reliable PD computation is important for robust and efficient simulation of dynamical systems. In addition to its high computational complexity, the resulting algorithms are also susceptible to accuracy and robustness problems.

Methods for computing the PD are less common. An algorithm for determining the PD of a pair of convex polyhedra has been presented in Cameron and Culley (1986). This algorithm has quadratic space and time bounds, since it requires an explicit representation of the configuration space obstacles (Minkowski sum). Cameron (1997) presents a faster method, however, this method returns an estimate for the magnitude of the PD.

Let P and Q be two intersecting polyhedra. The PD of P and Q, PD(P;Q), is the minimum translational distance that one of the polyhedra must undergo to render them disjoint. Formally, PD(P;Q) is defined as

$$ {\text{min}} \{||d||\;|{\text{interior}}(P + d) \cap Q=\phi\} .$$
(1)

Here, d is a vector in R 3. In practice, we represent the amount of PD, as a negative number in order to distinguish it from the ordinary Euclidean or separation distance between non-overlapping objects.

The computation of the PD between two polyhedral models is a global problem, and is rather difficult to localize it using some “divide-and-conquer” approach. A local solution computed using intersecting features or boundaries may not be correct. Table 1 shows the classification of the PQ problem.

The rest of the paper is structured as follows. Section 2 presents some of the previous works and describes some of the developed algorithms. A brief description of the bounding volume hierarchies (BVH) is shown in Sect. 3. A basic algorithm for convexity decomposition is shown in Sect. 4. Section 5 describes the proposed algorithm, while the simulation results are discussed in Sect. 6. Finally, some concluding remarks as well as directions for possible future extensions of this work are given in Sect. 7.

Previous work

Distance computation and collision detection problems have been fundamental subjects of study in robotics, computational geometry, simulation, and physical-based modeling. There is a wealth of literature on both analyzing the theoretical complexity of PQ and on designing algorithmic solutions to achieve interactive performance. This section will show some known algorithms about the hierarchical representation, the PD, and the PQ computation. It also shows three available packages for proximity queries computation.

Hierarchical representations

BVH are presently regarded as one of the most general methods for performing PQ between general polyhedra, specifically, sphere trees, cone trees, axis-aligned bounding box (AABB) trees, oriented bounding box (OBB) trees, K-D trees and octrees, trees based on S-bounds, and k-dops have been used for fast intersection queries for general polyhedra as well as polygon soups (Hubbard 1993; Quinlan 1994; Gottschalk et al. 1996; Cameron 1991; Klosowski et al. 1998). For most scenarios, these hierarchies excel at intersection detection but do not do so well when it comes to distance computation.

Penetration depth computation

PD computation is often used in motion planning (Hsu et al. 1998), contact resolution for dynamic simulation (McKenna and Zeltzer 1990; Stewart and Trinkle 1996), and force computation in haptic rendering (Kim et al. 2002). For example, computation of dynamic response in penalty-based methods often needs to perform PD queries for imposing the non-penetration constraint for rigid body simulation. In addition, many applications such as motion planning and dynamic simulation require a continuous distance measure, when two non-convex objects collide for a well-posed computation. Several algorithms for PD computation involve computing Minkowski sums and the closest point on its surface from the origin. The worst-case complexity of the overall PD algorithm is dominated by computing Minkowski sums, which can be O(n2) for convex polytopes and O(n6) for non-convex polyhedral models (Dobkin et al. 1993). A randomized algorithm to compute the PD is given in Agarwal et al. (2000). Given the worst-case, O(mn) complexity of PD computation between convex polytopes, a number of approximation approaches have been proposed for interactive applications. All of them either compute a subset of the boundary or a simpler approximation of the Minkowski sum and compute an upper or lower bound to the PD (Cameron 1997; Bergen 2001; Lin and Canny 1991; Ong and Gilbert 1996). They also take advantages of frame-to-frame coherence and perform incremental computations. Other approximation approaches for general polygonal models are based on discretized distance fields. These include algorithms based on fast marching level-sets for 3D models (Fisher and Lin 2001) and others based on graphics rasterization hardware and multi-pass rendering for 2D objects (Hoff et al. 2001).

Proximity queries for convex polyhedra

Most of the earlier work has focused on algorithms for convex polyhedra. A number of algorithms with good asymptotic performance have been proposed in the computational geometry literature (Edelsbrunner 1985). Using hierarchical representations, an optimization techniques are used in Gilbert et al. (1988) to compute the distance between convex polyhedra.

In applications involving rigid motion, geometric coherence has been exploited to design algorithms for convex polyhedra based on either traversing features using locality or convex optimisation (Cameron 1997; Lin and Canny 1991; Mirtich 1998; Dworkin and Zeltzer 1993). These algorithms exploit the spatial and temporal coherence between successive queries.

The Gamma group of the University of North Carolina had developed three packages for PQ computation: SWIFT++, PIVOT and IMMPACT.

SWIFT++

SWIFT++ is a collision detection package capable of detecting intersection, performing tolerance verification, computing approximate and exact distance, or determining the contacts between pairs of objects in a scene composed of general 3D polyhedral objects undergoing rigid motion. It operates by first computing a surface decomposition of the input models. The pieces are then grouped hierarchically using convex hulls. Pair of BVHs is tested using an improved Lin-Canny closest feature tracking algorithm.

PIVOT: proximity information from Voronoi techniques

PIVOT is a 2D proximity engine. This package utilizes hardware-accelerated multi-pass rendering techniques and distance computation to perform a variety of PQ between objects. These not only included in detecting collisions but also in computing intersections, separation distance, PD, and contact points and normals. It is based on using a hybrid geometry and image-based approach that balances computation between CPU and graphics subsystems. Geometric object-space techniques coarsely localize potential intersection regions or closest features between two objects, and image-space techniques compute the low-level proximity information in these localized regions. Most of the proximity information is derived from distance field computed using graphics hardware.

IMMPACT

IMMPACT may be used on massive models composed of millions of geometric primitives. It is based on an algorithm using overlap graphs for localizing the “regions of interest” within the model, thereby reducing runtime memory requirements. The overlap graph is computed off-line, pre-processed using graph partitioning algorithms, and modified on the fly as needed. At run time it traverses localized sub-graphs to check the corresponding geometry for proximity and pre-fetch geometry and auxiliary data structures. To perform interactive PQ, it uses BVH and takes advantage of spatial and temporal coherence.

Bounding volume hierarchies

The following equation in Gottschalk et al. (1996) and Klosowski et al. (1998) is to evaluate various types of BHV

$$ T-N_{u} \times C_{u} + N_{p} \times P_{p} $$
(2)

where T is the total cost of collision detection between two objects; N u is the number of primitives updates during the traversal; C u is the cost of updating a primitive’s positioning orientation; N p is the number of overlap tests performed; P p is the cost of an overlap test between a pair of primitives. Typically, for tight-fitting bounding volumes, e.g., OBBs, N u and N p are relatively small, whereas C u is relatively high. In contrast, C u is low while N u and N p may be larger for simple BV types like spheres and AABBs. Due to these opposing trends, no single BV yields optimum performance for PQ in all situations.

The performance of BVHs on PQ is governed by a number of design parameters, including techniques to build the trees, the maximum number of children per node, and the choice of BV type. An additional design choice is the descent rule. This is the policy for generating recursive calls when a comparison of two BVs does not prune the recursion branch. For instance, if BVs A and B failed to prune, one may recursively compare A with each of the children of B, B with each of the children of A, or each of the children of A with each of the children of B. This choice does not affect the correctness of the algorithm, but may impact the performance. Some of the commonly used algorithms assume that the BVHs are binary trees and each primitive is a single triangle or a polygon.

The bounding boxes technique is used to approximate the objects for a rough PQ computation. Two kinds of bounding boxes are used in the literature namely the AABB and the OBB. It has been proved that AABB are inferior to OBB, but they are easier and faster to compute. Two types of AABB exist: fixed and dynamic size. With the fixed size AABB, boxes may be generated by taking the maximum and minimum of the object with all the possible orientations and then taking the maximum and the minimum of those maximums and minimums obtained. The dynamic size AABB needs to be updated dynamically at every time step. The fixed size bounding boxes are simpler, because there is no need to recalculate the new maximum and minimum of objects in each step movement. This paper proposes the use of fixed size AABB.

For constructing the AABB tree, one need first to find the minimum and maximum point orthogonally projected onto the x, y and z axes. Having these extreme points, the plans equation of these boxes could be easily calculated. Then the algorithm divides the original AABB into eight parts. This division is done by selecting the mid-point between the minimum and the maximum on each axis. Then those obtained parts are considered as new AABB and divided again using the same technique. The first obtained AABB of the whole object is known as the first level AABB and at each division step a new level is constructed. Every AABB is known as a parent for the other AABBs generated from it. The generated AABB are known as descendants. Note that if two AABB are not in collision this implicitly means that their children are not as well. The generation of the tree may stop when the new AABB is enclosing only one facet of the object. Figure 1 shows a first level fixed size AABB for four different bones of the human wrist.

Convexity detection and decomposition

Given two facets i and j having vertices {M, N, O} and {M, N, P} respectively. Their planes may be represented by the following inequalities:

$$ \begin{aligned} a_{i}x+& b_{i}y + c_{i}z \leq d_{i}\\ a_{j}x+& b_{j}y + c_{j}z \leq d_{j}. \end{aligned} $$
(3)

The couple of facets belongs to the same convex set if their inner angle θ is \(0^{\circ}<\theta<180^{\circ}.\) In other words, if point P that belongs to plane j and verifies the inequality of plane i, the two planes belong to the same convex set. This means that

$$ a_{i}x^{P} + b_{i}y^{P} + c_{i}z^{P} \leq d_{i}\quad \Rightarrow \quad \text{convex} .$$
(4)

This method could be used when decomposing objects into set of convex ones. The decomposition approach consists of the following: starting form an arbitrary facet i, the algorithm will check its convexity with all its neighbors; if i is convex with the neighbor j, the algorithm consider i and j as a set of convex facets. This procedure will go over all the neighbors of i and the neighbors of the facets that are convex with it until no more convexity is detected. Then another facet k is selected randomly and the process is repeated again until all the facets of the objects was visited at least once.

Proximity queries and penetration depth computation

PQ is in fact a “premature” collision detection in VR. This paper discusses a novel method to calculate the proximity vector. In this approach, the PQ problem is first formulated as an optimisation problem and then solved by using linear programming. Each pair of convex objects in the scene is treated separately. For non-convex objects the algorithm of decomposition into convex polyhedra mentioned in Sect. 4 is used, and each convex part will then be considered as a separated object. Each object is composed by a set of triangular facets representing its boundaries. In the formulation process, each facet i is represented by their planes inequality

$$ a_{i}x + b_{i}y + c_{i}z \leq d_{i} .$$
(5)

Since the time step is small enough, one can approximate all the movements in the scene to be locally translational without any level of details degradation. The movement of the objects in the scene is considered to be with constant velocity. Having this in hand, the problem may be reformulated by adding a variable t representing the time to the equation of each facet i as follows:

$$ a_{i}x + b_{i}y + c_{i}z + e_{i}t \leq d_{i} .$$
(6)

Any point that lies inside the object must verify all the inequalities that formed this object. The set of formulated inequalities represents the constraints of the optimisation problem. Having this formulation, if a point verifies two sets of inequalities simultaneously, then this point belongs to their corresponding objects and so a collision is detected at that point between those two objects. This collision will take place at the time t. Thus the obtained solution will be a direction vector with a value of time t. Since the velocity is taken to be constant, the distance D is proportional to t and hence D is known. The proximity vector of two objects will be then obtained by minimizing t subject to their constraints simultaneously. However one must take the exterior of the object instead of its interior. This will lead to change the inequality in the plans equations. Hence, the PQ problem may be formulated as follows:

$$ \begin{aligned} \text{min}\;c^{\text{T}}\chi\\ \text{s.t.}\;A \chi \ge b \end{aligned} $$
(7)

where

$$ A=\left[{\begin{array}{llll} {a_{1}} & {b_{1}} & {c_{1}} & {e_{1}}\\ {a_{2}} & {b_{2}} & {c_{2}} & {e_{2}}\\ . & . & . & .\\ . & . & . & .\\ \end{array}} \right],\;b=\left[ {\begin{array}{l} {d_{1}}\\ {d_{2}}\\ .\\ .\\ \end{array}} \right],\\ c=\left[ {\begin{array}{llll} 0 & 0 & 0 &1\\ \end{array}} \right]^{\text{T}}\quad\text{and}\quad\chi=[x,\;y,\;z,\;t]^{\text{T}} .$$
(8)

In the model, the number of constraints is equal to the sum of the facets in the objects. This means that the number of facets increase as the number of constraints increase. Having too many constraints may increase the algorithm computational time. To improve the algorithm performance, the above maximization problem is first converted minimization problem by duality. The dual problem solved has the following form:

$$ \begin{aligned} \text{max}\;b^{\text{T}}\lambda\\ \text{s.t.}\;A^{\text{T}} \lambda \le c. \end{aligned} $$
(9)

In the dual problem, the number of constraints becomes constant (three), while the number of dual variables λ varies depending on the original number of the planes.

Depending of the sign of t the obtained results will be the PQ vector if t is positive and the PD vector if it is negative. It is a powerful and quick algorithm, but it must be applied on a pair of convex objects at a time. This algorithm was tested on the virtual surgery models of the human wrist and knee and satisfying results were obtained.

Simulation results

The proposed algorithm described in this paper is implemented using the Visual C++ version 6.0 under Windows operating system. It has been tested on a Siemens Fujistu Amilo Pro having a Pentium M 1.4 MHz processor and 512 M of RAM. Different tests were performed and their results are shown in Table 2.

There is no standard way to compare different algorithms and implementations. However, according to the results shown above one can conclude that the proposed algorithm is a very simple yet powerful and rapid algorithm for PD and PQ calculation.

Conclusions and perspectives

In this paper, a fast and accurate algorithm for PD and PQ calculation is presented. It does not make any assumption on the objects. The algorithm was tested on hundred of thousand of facets, and the results show that the algorithm is very fast and increases linearly with the number of facets. This proposed algorithm could be easily used for collision detection as well as for PD and PQ calculation. This feature makes it an appropriate tool for the construction of a VR package.

We are now investigating another approach for convex decomposition. It is known as the T-convex approximated decomposition where T is a threshold value of concavity. Facets having concavity less than T are considered to be convex. The convex hull of those obtained T-convex objects will be formulated and the algorithm will proceed as before.

It is quite obvious that PQ and PD computation is a requirement in almost all systems that animate graphical objects, or which need to determine potential collisions with real objects in advance. This poses a significant challenge in the area of real-time systems, and as the demand for more realism and interaction in such systems is constantly increasing, it is also likely to remain a challenge for quite some time in the future.
